subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Quickscript Unicode Proposal
msgSnippet: I just wanted to say I think it s great something s being done on this; I ve been writing in Quickscript quite a bit lately and I think it would be great to
messageBody:
I just wanted to say I think it's great something's being done on this; I've been writing in Quickscript quite a bit lately and I think it would be great to have it in Unicode.  I don't know much about all this, but at least I know what Unicode is, and I see that Quickscript will need to be represented in Unicode if it is ever going to be widely promoted.
   So, thanks to those who are working on this project, and I hope it makes some progress!

 -Benjamin Bruce


On 4/11/06, amd64_hacker < amd64_hacker@...> wrote:
Hi,

I saw your proposal in the files area but it didn't open correctly on my
machine (just got a blank page) so I assumed it was a work in progress,
I've re downloaded it and I see that's not the case (I can see the table
now, the qs glyphs remain invisible for some reason).

Personally I think that reusing shavian characters would be more trouble
than help, but I'm not expert enough on either script to have a strong
opinion on this.
I totally agree with you on ligatures and different representations of
the same glyph, this is defiantly some thing that should be kept out of
the mapping, it's the font system's job to render the text.
The only other thing I would add is that it would be nice to reuse the
numbers from the quikscript manual and have glyphs 0-39 as 1-40 or is
there a reason we don't want this?

oliver langan wrote:
> > Welcome to the group.
> >
> > The unicode mapping hasn't gotten off the ground yet.  I would like to
> > get this moving, but it seems like everyone is too busy.
> > If you know anything about this, we would welcome all the help we can
> > get.  You can install a font so that you can use QS on your computer.
> >
> > Paige
>
> Hi amd, jj, and of course Paige et al.
>
> Actually, I think that the proposed Unicode mapping available in the
> (Read_Alphabet) files area is pretty good... of course, I wrote it,
> so... :)
>
> One thing that is not included in the proposal document is the
> relationship between the Read Alphabet (Quickscript) and the Shaw
> Alphabet (Shavian).  Given that Shavian already has a Unicode mapping,
> it would probably be possible to re-use those encodings for glyphs
> which exist in both scripts.  We would only need to add glyphs for
> "why" "loch" "llan" "excite" and "examine".  However, I have two
> reservations about this.  Firstly, there is the overloaded "ado/up"
> vowel, for which there are two characters in shavian but only one in
> quickscript.  Secondly, the shavian proposal included several
> diphthongs as separate glyph encodings, "ian" "ear" "air" etc.  These
> really should NOT be separate glyphs: they should be entered and
> stored as two separate glyphs, and only presented as ligatures when
> they are displayed.  Giving ligatures a separate encoding will play
> hell with sorting/searching, etc.  In the same way, characters for
> which there are multiple glyphs, such as the multiple ways of writing
> "may" and "no", should have only a single encoding but multiple
> associated glyphs.
>
> What certainly has not gotten off the ground is a formal Unicode
> proposal.  According to:
>       http://www.unicode.org/pending/proposals.html *
> the proposal process can take quite a long time--years--especially for
> entire scripts.
>
> A good first step is to gather comments from interested partied (that
> would be all you people on this list), so that the proposed mapping
> can be modified if necessary.  Then, sending a semi-formal notice of
> intent to the Unicode mail list is probably a good next step to take.
> And of course, starting work on a first draft of the formal proposal.
> As I recall, the formal proposal is a bit confusing... but I am sure
> we can all muddle through it.
>
> oliver
>
> * The Unicode site was down earlier today when I was looking at it;
> but the google cache was available.
